ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Improved my Chinese speaking, vocabulary, grammar, writing, and listening
I improved my Chinese writing, speaking, and listening abilities-- in this course, I primarily developed reading comprehension skills.
Intermediate-advanced Chinese, especially more advanced grammar patterns and vocabulary.
I learned how to read and write in Chinese, and sharpened my oral abilities.
Learned a lot about Chinese vocabulary and proper grammar usage in the context of social and traditional settings.
My vocabulary and grammar improved a lot! Liu Laoshi is such a great professor and I truly learned a lot from her class.
Gained deeper understanding of Chinese grammar, vocabulary and nuances of the culture
I developed my Chinese skills in writing, reading, listening, and speaking.

- Chinese daily life and culture
- Speaking, writing, reading, grammar

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very organized, stuck to a very detailed schedule that was very helpful and also updated during the semester (so it remained accurate)

I think the teaching style, especially in the smaller group sizes, was very friendly and welcoming. I really liked being able to practice speaking and answering questions in class. The only weakness was that the teacher would announce the questions ahead of time, so everyone had a lot of time to prepare answers, which meant I did not develop my speed and fluency with verbal response as much.

Daily class strengthens practice and reinforces learning. Class time was very conducive to participation. Homework and tests were reasonable and fair. Schedule was very clear and organized, allowed students to focus on the learning.
I think the course has no weaknesses.

Strengths - all
Weaknesses - none
This course was really excellent! I enjoyed how it meets every day and I really feel like my Chinese has improved a lot over the course of the semester.
Strengths: class rigor greatly improved my vocabulary and oral proficiency

The course was very organized and it was very helpful to have the structure for the class schedule from the very start of the semester. I also loved having the asynchronous day to process some of the material and have a small break from the rather tiring schedule every week. One weakness was that there wasn't as much speaking and listening practice through the assignments and homework, which I would have preferred to have rather than limiting it to only the context of the classroom.

The pacing of one lesson covered in the span of three class days was far too fast to allow for proper review and study of the content. I would recommend adjusting the lesson schedule to be more slow-paced.

Strengths:
- The course is very well-organized
- Liu Laoshi is wonderful! She facilitates a very non-judgmental and friendly environment. I feel more confident in my Chinese after this course

Weaknesses:
- The asynchronous assignments sometimes took me way longer than our normal homework (e.g. when we had to watch a 2-hour movie and then create a presentation on it)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's great for improving Chinese, the professor's are great. It is a higher workload though.
Yes. It is a great class for anyone who wants to further their Chinese abilities, and I felt that it was especially well-tailored to heritage speakers.
Yes, not only to fulfill a language requirement but if you want to learn a language the right way!
For a Chinese American student who wants to improve their Chinese, I would recommend this course.
Yes. Great course although daily workload is significant with all of the quizzes and projects, keeping up will allow you to learn soo much and develop your skills.
Yes!! You should absolutely take a class with Liu Laoshi if you get the chance -- she is so kind, chill, and amazing at explaining nuanced grammatical points. She is the best.

Yes, this is an excellent course for heritage speakers looking to refine their oral, reading, an writing skills in Chinese. It was challenging in terms of rigor, lesson pacing, and workload, but at the end I felt like I had improved by leaps and bounds.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in improving your Chinese in any aspect! You can also learn about Chinese culture more.
Yes! Although the workload can be heavy, Liu Laoshi is very kind and understanding.
